> More strikingly, the intonation contrast relying on pitch register in ZM and, by a reasonable extension, in Standard Mandarin, is perceived gradiently, while that relying on pitch shape in Cantonese is perceived discretely.
>
> This is the first result to our knowledge that shows the phonological relevance of the manner in which intonational contrasts are phonetically specified. Our general interpretation of this result is that gradience in speech pitch signaling is not tonally encoded, while discreteness always is.
